text: [Music]
um I think to to each her own I really
do think it's it's not the answer for
everyone and I don't like um to think
that people you know to make that choice
because of the career uh I think is not
it doesn't really guarantee you anything
so I I wouldn't want people to put all
their eggs in that basket for the career
on the other hand um to hear someone who
is a passionate and committed writer say
you know what this gives me time to do
some writing this gives me time to work
on a manuscript and that's how I'm
thinking about the year uh I think that
that's a wonderful and sensible thing to
do um it's great if you can get a
fellowship to do that um and you know it
used to be when there are fewer of them
um that a fellowship you know a paid
year in graduate school made a
tremendous amount of sense made more
sense than anything else in a way uh as
a way to try to get a first book done um
I think study is good I think Community
is good um do I think that you know
there are positive uh creative
communities in all MFA programs no um in
some absolutely absolutely um and so you
see people who make um their communities
of readers for life um or who are able
to Apprentice themselves with a teacher
who changes their life that was
certainly the case for me me uh studying
with Derek Walcott he was you know the
only poetry teacher I ever had and he
was the teacher who changed my life and
that and that was that so if you're
lucky enough to make that connection
then absolutely of course it's worth it
um I think also you know for MFA
programs that have a a classroom
component that's not just a creative
writing Workshop so that in other words
designate some time in your life um to
you know really really really read and
and and soak up a lot I think that's
great alth though I also think for any
artist and for any poet there is no
substitute for
autodidacticism you know that that that
you have to have a reading Hunger that
leads you on your own path um that
that's a very very very important part
to My Mind of being an
artist there are so many poets who make
a life in the work and do their work but
that's not necessarily
measurable in conventionally successful
ways um you look at uh there's a a very
great poet who died about a year ago
named Christopher Christopher Gilbert
who wrote a book called across the
mutual landscape and he published this
book about 25 years ago um it was a book
kind of an underground hit with um so I
know many poets for whom this is a
secret special book for them and he was
a practicing I think psychotherapist he
had another professional life apparently
he was was writing poems uh and kept
writing poems but the Legacy as we know
it now is that one book but it was a
very beautiful and important book so you
know how do you put that against the
career of Someone Like An Adrien Rich
right who publishes her first book of
poems in the Yale series of younger
poets when she's in college you know
she's 20 or 21 or something when aen
picks that book and now as an elder um
she had a whole steady productive I mean
that's that's a life in in the Arts
that's another kind of success and so
even though you know poem for poem there
are many Rich poems that are indelible
and Incredibly important to me but I
also learned so much from the whole
career the whole life so there there's
so many different ways that it it plays
out you see and in different ways that I
would think of um of success so um I
think that that that it's a mysterious
perseverance that keeps you
going when I teach creative writing um
I'm a great believer in free writing in
you know that whole concept of taking
the sensor off your shoulder and of when
you feel stuck especially um just trying
to let it all out to to write without
stopping um and then deal with the
fixing up later um that can be very very
difficult because some sometimes you
know it's page upon page day upon day
week upon week of drek you know
sometimes it's un beauutiful it's
uncompelling and you just have to keep
moving through it you have to keep
moving forward um but I think that that
kind of um just letting it come and
knowing that somewhere in the tumble
down the river there's going to be a a
stone that's that's that that's got a
particular Sheen to it and that's what
you build on um I think that's the most
important thing is not to
stop I think you know one of the
important things that i' I've seen in
places where to poetry is taught well to
young people is to realize that they
have got they they're not yet afraid of
it and they are still unselfconsciously
in love with sound um and also they're
fantastic memorizers kids can memorize
so much because you know their brains
are are are and and and spongy um so um
I think to have to memorize and
recite um before you think of it as cod
liver oil is um is a very very very good
thing because then you have that
wonderful experience of possessing a
poem and also of feeling how it exists
in the voice which sometimes makes it
very exciting in a way you know you can
sort of experience The rhythms in a way
that might not always Le be clear on a
first reading on the paper um and then
finally I would say just the continued
and Avid teaching of poetry and to teach
that you know yes we go back to it we
study it we try to unpack how it works
but we also need to take it in as music
um and I think that that that
remembering that aspect of reading
poetry is is very
important when I see some of the cool
things um let's say that you know the
Poetry Foundation is doing or you know
um when I I see these things where oh
you know here's here's Langston Hughes
on A Street in Harlem here he is with
Charles Mingus uh you know doing his uh
The Weary Blues I mean why not take
digital and multimedia capabilities as a
way of bringing poems into three
dimension it's great I um recorded and
it was such a pleasurable project a um
podcast for the Poetry Foundation where
they do a literary tour of Washington DC
which is my hometown which is you know
you're supposed to they they paste it
out uh you're supposed to put on your
iPod and go out and start walking and
see uh and learn about the literary
Heritage and you know you can stop in
front of whatever historical site you
know this is the corner where Walt
Whitman uh would would shyy wave to
Abraham Lincoln and then they there's
Lincoln's voice in your ears while you
stand on that corner uh what's not to
like about that
